items.title: 6 new tech unicorns were minted in January 2025 so far.
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Six new tech unicorns were identified in January 2025, highlighting ongoing venture capital activity despite a tight market.
- The newly minted unicorns include: 
  - **Kikoff** valued at **$1 billion**, focuses on personal finance.
  - **NetraDyne** valued at **$1.35 billion**, specializes in computer vision with a recent $90 million series D.
  - **Hippocratic AI** valued at **$1.6 billion**, creates healthcare models and raised $141 million.
  - **Truveta** valued at **$1 billion**, known for genetic research, raised $320 million.
  - **Mercor** valued at **$2 billion**, an AI recruiting startup that raised $100 million.
  - **Loft Orbital** valued at **$1 billion**, a satellite company that raised $170 million.

items.title: Rivian inches closer to profitability but warns ‘changes to government policies’ could hurt
items.author: Sean O’Kane, Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Rivian's cost-cutting measures bring it closer to profitability, despite challenges expected in 2025.
- The company plans to deliver between 46,000 and 51,000 EVs in 2025, but warns of potential impacts from changes in government policies, particularly from the new Trump Administration.
- Rivian generated $1.7 billion in revenue for Q4 2024, a 32% increase from Q4 2023, with significant revenue from both vehicle sales and software services.

items.title: CEO of Clearview AI, a controversial facial recognition startup, has resigned
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Hoan Ton-That, CEO of Clearview AI, resigned, stating it is time for the next chapter in his life.
- Clearview AI now has co-CEOs: Hal Lambert and Richard Schwartz, aiming to leverage new opportunities.
- Clearview AI has faced numerous legal challenges and substantial GDPR fines exceeding $100 million but has achieved high growth and revenue in 2024.

items.title: Your Android phone could have stalkerware. Here’s how to remove it
items.summary:
- Consumer-grade spyware apps can monitor private messages, photos, calls, and location on Android devices.
- This guide helps identify and remove stalkerware such as [TheTruthSpy](https://techcrunch.com/2022/10/26/inside-thetruthspy-stalkerware/), [Cocospy](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/20/stalkerware-apps-cocospy-spyic-exposing-phone-data-of-millions-of-people/), and [Spyic](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/20/stalkerware-apps-cocospy-spyic-exposing-phone-data-of-millions-of-people/).
- Stalkerware is disguised as child monitoring or family-tracking software, often installed without consent.
- Possible signs of infection include unusual phone behavior, excessive data use, and performance issues.
- Key steps to mitigate stalkerware include enabling [Google Play Protect](https://techcrunch.com/2023/11/04/google-play-android-real-time-app-scanning-sideload-apps/), checking accessibility services, and reviewing notification access settings.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s makeover didn’t make people like him, study shows
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- A Pew Research Center study revealed that 67% of U.S. adults have an unfavorable view of Mark Zuckerberg, while 54% feel negatively about Elon Musk.
- Zuckerberg's attempts to rebrand himself through fashion and music have not improved public perception, especially among left-leaning demographics.
- The survey involved 5,086 randomly selected U.S. adults and was conducted from Jan. 27 to Feb. 2, 2025.

items.title: Hacked, leaked, exposed: Why you should never use stalkerware apps
items.summary:
- Stalkerware apps are marketed to individuals wanting to monitor partners, leading to significant data privacy breaches.
- At least 23 stalkerware companies have faced hacks or data leaks since 2017, with Cocospy and Spyic being the latest offenders in 2025.
- Cocospy and Spyic leaked 2.65 million customer email addresses and various personal data.
- Several high-profile breaches have occurred, including those of mSpy and pcTattletale, leading to widespread data exposure.
- Experts highlight that stalkerware apps are a risky choice due to the dangerous implications for victims and the untrustworthiness of the companies behind them.

items.title: Bankrupt Nikola wants to sell its whole business by April
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Electric trucking startup Nikola aims to sell its business by April following its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.
- The company has at least three interested buyers and plans to solicit more bids by late March.
- If no full buyer is found, Nikola will consider selling off assets to address over $1 billion in liabilities.
- CEO Stephen Girsky mentioned previous attempts to find buyers, with various negotiations ultimately failing.
- A hearing on potential sales is expected in April, with the urgency due to Nikola's limited cash reserves of around $47 million.

items.title: Stalkerware apps Cocospy and Spyic are exposing phone data of millions of people
items.summary:
- A security vulnerability in Cocospy and Spyic, phone-monitoring apps, exposes personal data of millions.  
- The vulnerability allows access to messages, photos, call logs, and email addresses of users.  
- The researcher collected over 2.65 million unique email addresses from both apps, marking the data as sensitive in Have I Been Pwned.  
- The apps, marketed for parental control and employee monitoring, are often used for spying without consent and are banned from app stores.  
- Cocospy launched in 2018 and Spyic in 2019, with evidence linking their operations to a China-based developer.  
- Users can check for the apps on their devices using specific codes and should enable security settings to protect against such vulnerabilities.

items.title: Meta starts accepting sign-ups for Community Notes on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Meta announced acceptance of sign-ups for Community Notes on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads.
- The move follows the end of Meta's third-party fact-checking program in favor of a Community Notes model.
- Users in the U.S., over 18, with accounts over six months old can sign up to contribute.
- Contributors can submit Notes to clarify misleading posts, which must include a link and adhere to a 500-character limit.
- Notes require agreement from users who usually disagree with each other to be published.
- The full rollout of Community Notes is planned over the next couple of months in the U.S., with no date for international expansion yet.
- Mark Zuckerberg indicated that the move permits more unrestricted speech online, citing perceived political bias in fact-checking.

items.title: Tesla to test virtual queues at Supercharging locations
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Tesla is piloting a virtual queuing system at Supercharging stations starting in the second quarter of 2025.
- This initiative is in response to escalating incidents of "EV charging rage" among drivers at crowded charging stations.
- The company aims to improve customer experience for the small percentage of users who experience wait times.
- A broader rollout will depend on positive feedback from the pilot.
- It's unclear if non-Tesla EV drivers will initially have access to this queuing system.

items.title: Beta Technologies’ bet on electric flight and Hyundai’s new Tesla charging port comes up short
items.summary:
- Beta Technologies is gaining flight hours in the electric aviation sector under CEO Kyle Clark.
- Nikola has filed for bankruptcy after failing to secure funding.
- Getaround shut down U.S. operations but will focus on Europe.
- Turo has postponed its IPO plans.
- Hyundai’s 2025 Ioniq 5 has a charging port issue with Tesla chargers.
- Lime reported another year of being free cash flow positive.

items.title: Electric aircraft founder Kyle Clark threw out the Silicon Valley playbook
items.summary:
- Over 800 people attended the maiden flight of Beta Technologies’ electric aircraft, the Alia CX300, piloted by CEO Kyle Clark, on November 13, 2024.
- Beta Technologies is headquartered in Vermont, rejecting the Silicon Valley model and venture capital in favor of a more independent funding approach, raising $1.15 billion from institutional investors.
- The company aims to have its Alia CX300 certified for commercial flight by 2026 and also plans operations with Air New Zealand, which has ordered multiple aircraft for mail delivery.

items.title: Trump’s FTC Launches Inquiry into Tech Platform Censorship
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) announced a public inquiry into censorship by tech platforms, seeking comments from affected users.
- FTC Chairman Andrew Ferguson emphasized the need to understand potential legal violations by these firms regarding user silencing and intimidation.
- The inquiry coincides with social media companies loosening restrictions on hate speech, raising questions about the relation between content moderation and the First Amendment.
- Legal experts argue that the inquiry might misinterpret the First Amendment, which restricts government interference with speech, not private companies.
- President Trump signed an executive order making independent regulators accountable to the White House, potentially affecting the FTC's inquiry.

items.title: Amazon shuts down Chime, its Zoom alternative
items.summary:
- Amazon confirms the shutdown of its video conferencing service [Chime](https://aws.amazon.com/chime/), effective February 20, 2026.
- New Chime accounts are no longer accepted as of February 19, 2025.
- Existing customers can still use the service until the end date but are urged to migrate data and switch to alternatives like [Wickr](https://techcrunch.com/2021/06/25/aws-is-buying-encrypted-messaging-service-wickr/), Zoom, or Slack.
- [Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-zoom-main-meeting-app-microsoft-365-2025-2) reports Amazon will transition to Zoom as its official meeting app moving forward.
- Chime was launched in 2017 but struggled with adoption outside Amazon, contributing to its closure.

items.title: In India, Apple’s iPhone 16e faces stiff competition from older models
items.summary:
- Apple unveiled the iPhone 16e, aimed at emerging markets, including India, replacing the iPhone SE and iPhone 14.
- India became Apple's fourth largest market in 2024, with record 12 million shipments and 35% YoY growth, expected to exceed 15 million this year.
- Older models like the iPhone 13 and 15 dominate sales, despite Android's overall market share.
- The iPhone 16e's price starts at 59,900 INR (~$689), with limited new features compared to older models, potentially discouraging buyers.
- Analysts suggest Apple's iPhone 16e might attract users away from older models but note its launch timing is unfavorably outside upgrade seasons.

items.title: Pre-seed firm Afore Capital has a fresh $185M fund and a new program to help founders discover ideas
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Afore Capital has launched a new $185 million fund and a program called pre-seed 2.0.
- The firm claims to be the largest dedicated pre-seed investor, with a portfolio valuation over $13.5 billion.
- They aim to provide flexible investment amounts, catering to both established founders and those in the ideation phase.
- Afore is starting an 8-week Founders-in-Residence (FIR) program to assist early-stage founders in exploring startup ideas without the immediate pressure to fundraise.
- The new fund will invest in 35 to 40 pre-seed companies and support 50 to 75 founders through the FIR program.

items.title: 61 US startups became unicorns in 2024: Here’s the full list
items.summary:
- 61 US startups became unicorns as of February 2024 despite a tight venture capital market.
- Notable unicorns include Elon Musk's xAI, valued at $24 billion, and several AI startups.
- Other sectors seeing success include cybersecurity, health tech, and fintech.
- The list includes startups like Fervo Energy ($1.4 billion), Speak ($1 billion), Anysphere ($2.6 billion), and numerous others across various months.
- The full list will be updated throughout the year, tracking the rising companies.

items.title: Inside the Humane acquisition: HP offers big raises to some, others immediately laid off
items.summary:
- Humane, a Silicon Valley AI hardware startup, was acquired by HP for $116 million, significantly lower than the $240 million it raised in venture capital.
- Following the acquisition, some employees received job offers with over 30% pay increases, while others were laid off, particularly those in roles related to the AI Pin devices.
- The new HP unit, HP IQ, will focus on integrating AI into HP's products and includes Humane's leadership and its AI operating system, CosmOS.
- It was reported that Humane had been struggling, with negative product reviews, safety issues, and ultimately more returns than sales for its AI Pin.

items.title: Cherryrock Capital raises new $172M fund from all-star investors to back diverse founders
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Cherryrock Capital has closed its $172 million Fund I, targeting investments in diverse founders.
- Founders include ex-TaskRabbit CEO Stacy Brown-Philpot, with notable investors like JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, and Melinda French Gates.
- Fund I focuses on Series A and B stages, particularly for later-staged investments in diverse founders.
- Closed in January 2025 after two years of fundraising efforts.
- Already backed two companies: Coactive AI and Vitable.

items.title: Figure’s humanoid robot takes voice orders to help around the house
items.author: Brett Adcock
items.summary:
- Figure's humanoid robot uses a new machine learning model called Helix to execute voice commands in households.
- Helix combines visual data and language prompts, allowing robots to perform tasks in real time.
- Robots utilize Helix to control and assist each other in household activities, tackling challenges of dynamic home environments.
- Teaching robots complex tasks in varied settings remains a significant hurdle, as they need extensive training for adaptive behavior. 
- The application of the Helix model represents a strategic shift for Figure, focusing more on household utility than just industrial applications.

items.title: Instagram’s new ad format lets creators get paid for testimonials in comments
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Instagram introduces a new ad format called Testimonials for creators to get paid for endorsements in comments.
- The format allows creators to post written endorsements on brands' social media posts, enhancing transparency.
- Creators can write short messages tied to campaigns, which will be pinned at the top of comments for visibility.

items.title: Spotify partners with ElevenLabs to expand its library of AI-narrated audiobooks
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Spotify announces support for audiobooks narrated using ElevenLabs’ AI voice technology.
- Authors can generate audiobooks in 29 languages; free version allows 10 minutes of narration per month, while the Pro plan costs $99/month for 500 minutes.
- This partnership follows Spotify's previous collaboration with Google Play Books for AI-narrated audiobooks and aims to enhance its audiobook library.
- The rise of AI audiobooks raises concerns about potential quality issues within the publishing industry.

items.title: California privacy regulator seeks to fine Florida data broker after huge breach of Social Security numbers
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- California Privacy Protection Agency (CPPA) seeks a $46,000 fine against National Public Data for failing to register as a data broker.
- National Public Data suffered a data breach in April 2024, impacting around 270 million individuals with approximately three billion records stolen.
- The company filed for bankruptcy, but a Florida court dismissed the petition, allowing further legal actions against it.
- CPPA's enforcement action is its sixth against a data broker since its establishment, following five settlements earlier.

items.title: Substack now lets creators monetize videos and post them directly from its app
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Substack allows creators to monetize videos and publish them directly from the app.
- Creators can now reach their audience and monetize work without relying on algorithms.
- Future plans include enabling teaser portions of videos for free subscribers and adding editing tools.
- Video adoption increased since 2022, with revenue growth for video creators more than 2.5 times faster than non-video creators.
- By February 2025, 82% of top creators utilized audio and video, with significant growth in subscriber willingness to pay for Substacks from audio and video creators.

items.title: Arize AI hopes it has first-mover advantage in AI observability
items.author: Jason Lopatecki, Aparna Dhinakaran, Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- Arize AI provides AI observability to monitor and evaluate AI models and applications.
- The platform supports various AI applications, focusing on pre- and post-launch evaluations.
- Co-founders Jason Lopatecki and Aparna Dhinakaran aim to tackle complexities in AI technology.
- Arize was launched in 2019 and has experienced rapid growth due to increased accessibility of AI.
- The company raised $70 million in Series C funding, totaling over $130 million to date.
- Arize works with enterprises like Uber and Klaviyo and has over two million monthly downloads for its open-source product, Arize Phoenix.

items.title: Twitch caps streamers’ storage at 100 hours of highlights and uploads
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Twitch will limit streamers to 100 hours of highlights and uploads, with deletions for exceeding the limit starting April 19.
- Highlights are being deemed ineffective in driving engagement, while features like Clips and Tags are more effective.
- Twitch operates this limit for less than 0.5% of active channels, aiming to manage storage costs and improve resource allocation.
- Streamers are encouraged to download their content before the deadline to avoid automatic deletions.

items.title: OpenAI now serves 400M users every week
items.summary:
- OpenAI has reached 400 million weekly active users, up from 300 million in December 2024.
- The company reports growth in enterprise plans, with 2 million paying users, doubling since September 2024.
- Developer traffic for OpenAI's APIs has also doubled over the past six months.
- This update comes shortly after China's DeepSeek released competitive AI technologies.

items.title: UK healthcare giant HCRG confirms hack after ransomware gang claims theft of sensitive data
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- HCRG Care Group is investigating a cybersecurity incident involving a breach claimed by the Medusa ransomware group.
- The group claims to have stolen over two terabytes of sensitive data, including personal, medical, and financial records.
- HCRG has over 5,000 employees and serves half a million patients in the UK.
- The ransomware group is demanding a $2 million ransom and threatens to publish the data if not paid.
- HCRG informed the U.K.’s Information Commissioner’s Office about the breach and continues to operate its services.

items.title: Mercor, an AI recruiting startup founded by 21-year-olds, raises $100M at $2B valuation
items.summary:
- Mercor, an AI recruiting startup founded by three 21-year-old Thiel Fellows, raised $100 million in a Series B round.
- The funding round values Mercor at $2 billion, eight times its previous valuation.
- Felicis led the investment, with participation from existing investors including Benchmark, General Catalyst, and DST Global.
- Mercor's platform automates hiring with resume screening, candidate matching, AI interviews, and payroll management.
- The system claims to remove bias from hiring processes, which is a debated topic in AI.
- Mercor now has a $75 million annual revenue run rate (ARR) with significant growth in demand for various professionals.
- The company helps identify job roles for humans in an AI-driven economy, emphasizing the importance of expert hiring.

items.title: SmartSuite raises $38M to be the final word on enterprise collaboration
items.author: Jon Darbyshire, Tara Darbyshire, Peter Novosel
items.summary:
- SmartSuite, a collaboration platform for enterprise teams, raised $38M in funding after seeing 300% growth in one year.
- The platform currently has 50,000 users from 5,000 businesses including notable clients like Apple Bank and UCLA.
- SmartSuite integrates project management, process management, and document management into one platform, supporting around 5,000 application integrations.

items.title: Amazon is shutting down its app store on Android
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Amazon will discontinue its app store for Android on **August 20, 2025**.
- Developers will no longer be able to submit new apps to the store after this date.
- The **Amazon Coins** digital currency will also be discontinued, with refunds provided for any coins held as of August 20.
- The app store will remain functional on Amazon's own devices like **Fire TV** and **Fire Tablet**.
- Amazon has been trying to compete with Google in the app store space since **2011** but has struggled with initiatives like the Fire Phone.

items.title: Valar Atomics comes out of stealth with $19M and a pilot reactor site
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- SMR companies raised over $1.5 billion this year due to demand for power in AI training and increased government commitments.
- Valar Atomics secured $19 million in seed funding for its first test reactor, led by Riot Ventures, with support from AlleyCorp, Initialized Capital, Day One Ventures, and Steel Atlas.
- Valar's technology features a helium-cooled, high-temperature gas reactor, aiming to streamline SMR production and significantly cut costs.
- The company will build reactors primarily off-grid to supply power for data centers and industrial sites, with an initial contract for a reactor in the Philippines.
- Valar's reactors can operate at temperatures up to 900°C, enabling efficient hydrogen production and low-carbon synthetic fuels.

items.title: Tether backs stablecoin liquidity provider Mansa in $10M seed round
items.summary:
- Dubai-based, Africa-focused startup Mansa raises $10 million in seed funding, led by Tether with a $3 million equity investment.
- Funding aims to support expansion into Latin America and Southeast Asia, addressing liquidity challenges in cross-border payments.
- Mansa reports a surge in transaction volume, reaching $11 million in January with a goal of $1 billion in total payment volume run rate this year.

items.title: Spore.Bio raises $23M to apply machine learning to microbiology testing
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Spore.Bio, a Paris-based startup, raises $23M in Series A funding to innovate microbiology testing in the food and beverage industry.
- The startup's technology reduces testing times from days to minutes using light and deep learning algorithms.
- Spore.Bio has multiple commercial contracts for 200 factories and plans to manufacture testing machines for on-site use.

items.title: AI-coding startup Codeium in talks to raise at an almost $3B valuation, sources say
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Codeium is raising funds at a $2.85 billion valuation, led by Kleiner Perkins.
- The new funding round follows a $150 million Series C funding at a $1.25 billion valuation just six months ago.
- Codeium's annualized recurring revenue (ARR) is about $30 million, resulting in a valuation of approximately 95 times ARR; higher than competitors.
- The startup focuses on enterprise customers and boasts over 1,000 enterprise clients like Anduril, Zillow, and Dell.
- Founded in 2021 by Varun Mohan and Douglas Chen, Codeium differentiates itself with its AI-enabled coding tools.

items.title: Patreon Speaks Out Against Algorithmic Feeds in Creator Economy
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Patreon released its 'State of Create' report highlighting challenges faced by creators due to algorithmic feeds.
- 53% of creators believe it's harder to reach followers than five years ago; fans prefer long-form content.
- 78% of creators say 'The Algorithm' influences their content, impacting their creative freedom and income potential.

items.title: Saronic raises $600M to mass-produce autonomous warships
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Austin-based defense startup Saronic raised $600 million in Series C funding to establish an autonomous ship factory called "Port Alpha."
- The funding was led by investor Elad Gil and increased Saronic's valuation to $4 billion.
- Saronic aims to construct large unmanned ships to enhance U.S. shipbuilding capabilities and compete with China.

items.title: Study Finds Far Right Bias in TikTok and X Feeds Ahead of German Elections
items.summary:
- Research by Global Witness shows TikTok and X amplify content favoring the Far Right AfD party ahead of Germany's federal elections.
- TikTok's algorithm recommended 78% and X's 64% of political content supporting the AfD to non-partisan users.
- Non-partisan users are exposed to right-leaning content over twice as much as left-leaning content.
- The study raises concerns about the lack of transparency in social media algorithms and their role in democratic discussions.
- Global Witness aims for investigations into potential political bias following its findings shared with EU officials.

items.title: After raising $1 billion, fintech Varo closes another $29 million, replaces founder CEO
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Varo raised $29 million in an SEC filing as part of its Series G round, aiming for $55 million total.
- The fintech has raised over $1 billion in funding since its inception in 2015.
- CEO and founder Colin Walsh stepped down, with Gavin Michael appointed as the new CEO.
- Walsh remains on Varo's board and retains a significant stake in the company.
- Varo became the first all-digital nationally chartered U.S. consumer bank in 2020 and is focusing on financial inclusion.

items.title: Uber ditches commissions in favor of daily fees for rickshaw drivers in India
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Uber shifts from a commission-based model to charging rickshaw drivers a daily fee in India, aiming to remain competitive against local rivals like Rapido and Namma Yatri.
- Drivers will pay between $0.23-$0.46 per day to use the Uber platform, replacing the previous commission structure of 25%-40% per ride.
- The change allows drivers to set their own fares, with payments made directly to them, while Uber will not handle fare disputes or cancellation charges.

items.title: Brand new women’s focused Swizzle Ventures skyrockets past its fundraising target
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Swizzle Ventures closed its Fund I at $6.6 million, surpassing its initial target of $3 million.
- Fund I will focus on women’s health and wealth, addressing issues like caregiving and finances.
- 70% of the fund’s LPs are women, and 50% are experts in the firm's focus areas.
- The firm intends to invest between $100,000 and $200,000 at pre-seed and seed levels and has already backed 11 companies.
- Swizzle Ventures launched in 2023 and aims to invest in a total of 30 companies from this fund.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s charity U-turns, ends DEI efforts
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg’s charity, the Chan-Zuckerberg Initiative (CZI), has ended its Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) programs despite previous commitments to staff. 
- CZI will no longer provide social advocacy funding, which included grants for racial equity and immigration reforms. 
- Internal programs such as the Science Diversity Leadership Awards and the Diverse Slate Practice have been canceled. 
- The decision comes amidst shifts in the regulatory landscape and aims to align CZI's focus with its mission as a science philanthropy. 
- This change follows a similar move by Meta, raising concerns among CZI employees about its commitment to DEI values.

items.title: Spanish spyware startup Mollitiam Industries shuts down
items.summary:
- Mollitiam Industries, a Spanish spyware maker, is shutting down due to financial issues.
- The company filed for bankruptcy on January 23, 2025, as reported by [Intelligence Online](https://www.intelligenceonline.com/surveillance--interception/2025/02/07/cumulative-pressures-force-spanish-cyberoffensive-leader-to-close,110372862-art).
- Known for developing spyware like Invisible Man and Night Crawler, the firm has mostly operated out of public view and had 11 to 50 employees.
- The company was linked to surveillance scandals, including one in Colombia involving threats against journalists.
- Mollitiam was active at least until the end of 2023, and its activities were monitored by organizations like Amnesty International.

items.title: IVF insurance startup Future Family promises a baby or your money back
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Future Family offers a new IVF insurance product with a money-back guarantee for unsuccessful treatments.  
- Couples pay 20% insurance upfront; refunds available if no baby after two IVF cycles.  
- Average insurance cost is $3,000 plus $999/month for five months, covering up to $50,000 in IVF-related expenses.  
- Eligibility criteria include age and medical history; those 38 and older using own eggs are ineligible.  
- Since 2016, Future Family has assisted over 10,000 families, distributing $200 million in credit and securing $150 million in total funding.

items.title: Karman+ digs up $20M to build an asteroid-mining autonomous spacecraft
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Karman+ raised $20 million for developing autonomous spacecraft for asteroid mining.
- The startup aims to extract water and rare metals from asteroids and use it to refuel satellites.
- Their first launch is planned for 2027, aiming to significantly reduce mission costs to under $10 million.
- Founded by Teun van den Dries and Daynan Crull, they plan to build a space manufacturing ecosystem.

items.title: This Week in AI: Maybe we should ignore AI benchmarks for now
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's AI startup xAI launched the Grok 3 model, outperforming leading models in various benchmarks.
- Criticism of AI benchmarks highlights their limited correlation to real-world task proficiency and the need for better testing methods.
- Ongoing debate exists among AI experts regarding the effectiveness of public benchmarks and alternative evaluation criteria based on economic impact and utility.

items.title: Google’s ‘Career Dreamer’ uses AI to help you explore job possibilities
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google launched a new AI experiment called [Career Dreamer](https://grow.google/career-dreamer/?utm_source=google&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=2025-career-dreamer__geo--Global&utm_content=grow-google-career-dreamer-blog) to help individuals explore career options.
- Users can create a career identity statement by selecting their roles, skills, experiences, and education.
- The tool provides visualization of career paths based on user background and interests.
- Unlike job platforms like Indeed, it focuses on career exploration rather than job postings.
- Currently available only in the United States; its future availability in other countries is uncertain.
- Developed in consultation with organizations supporting diverse groups including students and veterans.

items.title: Google pulls Gemini from main search app on iOS
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Google is discontinuing its AI assistant Gemini's availability in the main Google app for iOS.
- Users are encouraged to download the dedicated Gemini app instead to access its features.
- The change may limit Gemini's reach as the main app has millions of users who may be reluctant to download a new application.
- An email notification sent to customers stated Gemini is no longer available in the Google app and prompted them to download it from the App Store.
- The Gemini app offers functionalities like voice conversations, integration with Google apps, image creation, and more.
- Users can upgrade to a paid subscription for features of Gemini Advanced through the iOS app.
- Those trying to access Gemini in the main app will be directed to download the new app.
- Google's strategy may result in reduced usage of Gemini as users may not transition smoothly to the new app.

items.title: ElectronX is building a stock market for electricity trading
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- ElectronX is creating an exchange for trading electricity to help manage risk associated with renewable energy.
- The company has raised $10 million, following a previous $15 million seed round in June 2024.
- The proposed market will allow trading in 1 megawatt blocks on an intra-hour or hourly basis, pending approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

items.title: Sanas taps AI to change call center workers’ accents in real time
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Sanas, founded in 2020, develops AI software that adjusts call center workers' accents in real time.
- The technology aims to reduce accent discrimination and preserve the speaker’s identity and emotion.
- Recently raised $48 million, valuing the company at over $500 million and planning to expand its workforce and capabilities.
